column4: Annales Laureshamenses, Annales Alamanni, Annales Nazariani, ed. MGH SS 1.24-5; Annales Petaviani, ed. MGH SS 1.7; Annales Mosellani, ed. MGH SS 16.494
column15: Gaul: rivers flood greatly; opposite in N. Africa which has a drought ca. 707-11 (711?)
column16: 711: Gaul? Austrasia? Aquae inundaverunt valde; et mors Hildeberti.  kg Childebert died early 711 (Grotefend 1971, 112). Dendrodata indicates AMJ drought in 710 and 711, wet in 712. If the year is correct in the annalistic tradition and the dendrodata is correct for these years, the floods may have occurred in the fall of 711.

column4: Annales regni Francorum, a. 784, 66; Annales Einhardi a. 784, 67, MGH SS rer Ger. Cf. Annales Mosellani a. 784, MGH SS 16.497
column15: continuous rains flood Weser, Charlemagne changes campaign route, May-July; Ann. Mosellani add, after 3 prominent deceases, mention of floods, without any explicit link to Saxony. Could therefore refer to Moselle region, as many entries into this set of Annals do: "nec non et inundatio aquarum pervalida fuit." See Comments for confirmation from dendrodata
column16: Cf. BM 266e for approximate date of floods in Saxony on Weser. Could have affected Austrasia more broadly, judging from lack of geographic specification in Annales Mosellani re floods of that year. In fact, AMJ were very wet in NE France, according to Büntgen et al. 2011; http://www.ncdc.noaa.gov/paleo/pubs/buentgen2011/buentgen2011.html FIg. 4 Recons.

column16: "Hinitus aqu(a)***. Text is corrupt. Jaffé in note suggests this MS's source could have read "inundatio aquarum" as ibid., anno 711, p. 686. Looks plausible. column15: 716-717: winter Rome: Tiber floods Rome for 7 days in indiction 15 (=Redaction 2) i.e. Sept. 1, 716-Aug 31, 717. Enters via Porta Flaminia. In the Via Lata it was 1.5 statura high, knocked over houses, etc. On day 8 receded. Niermeyer 1993. s.v. interprets statura as "height of a man" so ca. 8-9 feet deep
